description: On 22nd May 2020, the Minister for Education and Employment Owen Bonnici and a representation of the academic staff of the Faculty for Education within the University of Malta launched a Covid-19 outreach programme to support a wide spectrum of learners, educators and parents. This programme includes a website called lovetoteach.info which is updated frequently and is built around four sections: one for junior and senior students, one for parents, one for parents, one for educators and educational leaders and one for higher-education students, adults and their educators.

description: On the 12th of March 2020, Malta initiated a travel ban on persons to and from Italy, Switzerland, France, Germany, Spain, China, including Hong Kong, Singapore, Japan, Iran, South Korea, ending in March 21st. UPDATE: From March 21 2020, the travel ban extends to persons to Malta and from Malta to and from all countries: Provided that (a) cargo flights, ferry flights, humanitarian flights, and repatriation flights shall be exempt from this order; (b) cargo ships including container ships and vessels carrying goods and essential commodities and tankers loaded with essential fuels are exempted from this order.

description:
On June 1st Malta announced it will reopen its borders from July 1st to sixteen countries including: 
Iceland
Slovakia
Cyprus
Lithuania
Israel
Norway
Switzerland
Estonia
Denmark
Hungary
Austria
Luxembourg
Germany
Czech Republic
Finland
Ireland

On June 15th, six countries were added to this list: 
Italy (except for Emilia Romagna, Lombardy and Piemonte)
France (except for Ile de Frace)
Spain (except for Madrid, Catalonia, Castilla -La Mancha, Castile and Leon)
Poland (except for Katowice Airport)
Greece
Croatia

Israel was originally included on the list but is now removed. UPDATE: The original announcement stated sixteen countries, on 15th June a further six countries were added to the list of destinations allowed to travel.
date_end_spec: The policy has an unlimited time span (e.g. recommendation to wash one's hands; passing of a legal bill)
target_geog_level: One or more countries and one or more regional groupings
enforcer: Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: March 10, 2020: The Maltese health authorities announced that a swab centre was opened in Luqa's Industrial Estate to check anyone for Covid-19 symptoms. However, only seven people can be swabbed at the same time and only people who have had preliminary testing done through the helpline or through a GP will be referred to this establishment. There will be a mobile team that will go to people's homes in case they cannot access the centre.

description: On the 26th March Malta announced it will impose a mandatory lockdown on vulnerable individuals commencing on 28th March. This group includes those who are: over 65 years old; pregnant; with chronic illness; insulin-dependent diabetics; biological medication; had chemotherapy in last six months; had a transplant or HIV treatment; on renal dialysis; respiratory problems who needed treatment in last year; cardiac problems in last six months; on oral steroids.

description:
On the 9th April 2020, the Maltese Government began a voluntary repatriation assistance scheme for all foreign nationals. The scheme is aimed at all foreign nationals, who either resided or who were here on a temporary visit, and who wish to be repatriated to their home country.
Assistance is also available to European Union citizens and third-country nationals who have been staying in Malta for different purposes such as employment, education and family reasons, among others. Foreign individuals who are not in possession of a residence document are also entitled to assistance.
date_end_spec: The policy has an unlimited time span (e.g. recommendation to wash one's hands; passing of a legal bill)
type_text: The Maltese Government is subsidising flights to help foreign nationals fly back to their home country in case they are stuck in Malta. The Maltese government had previously helped individuals from Italy, Spain, France, Germany and Switzerland who were stranded in Malta due to flight closures fly back home. They are now extending the help to people from other countries who are also stuck in Malta.
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:

(b)  Cyprus;(c)  Czech Republic;(d)  Denmark;(e)  Estonia;(f)  Finland;(g)  Hungary;(h)  Iceland;(i)  Ireland;(j)  Germany;(k)  Latvia;(l)  Lithuania;(m) Luxembourg;(n)  Norway;(o)  Italy;(p)  France;(q)  Slovakia;(r)  Switzerland;(s)  Greece;(t)  Croatia;(u)  Spain ;(v)  Poland;
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Quarantine outside the home or government facility (i.e. quarantine in a hotel)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
compliance: Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)

description:
On March 22nd 2020, Malta closed all non-essential shops and services to stop the spread of coronavirus, Health Minister Chris Fearne said on Sunday, with the Mediterranean island following the lead of many other European Union states.

“All shops except those selling essential items such as food, medical services and pet shops will close from 8.00 am on Monday,” Fearne told reporters as the number of confirmed virus cases in the country rose to 90.
date_end_spec: The policy has an unlimited time span (e.g. recommendation to wash one's hands; passing of a legal bill)
institution_status: This type of business  ("All or unspecified businesses") is closed/locked down
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description:
Since March 23, non-essential retail was stopped. This includes outlets selling clothes, jewellery, toys, videogames, books, electronics and household goods, among others. Excluded from this prohibition are supermarkets, bakeries, groceries and pet shops, among others. Non-essential services will also be stopped. This includes hairdressers, beauticians and tattooists, among others. Excluded from this prohibition are postal services, medical services, transport services and banks. With effect from Monday 4th May 2020, some commercial establishments will be allowed to open once again. These include:
Lotto Shops
VRT Testing Centres
Clothes Shops
Sport Shops
Jewellery Shops (even Costume Jewellery)
Shoe Shops
Haberdashery
Discount Stores
Luggage and Travel Shops
Toys
Hobby Shops
Florists
Furniture Shops
Perfumeries
Opticians UPDATE: Since March 23, non-essential retail was stopped. This includes outlets selling clothes, jewellery, toys, videogames, books, electronics and household goods, among others. As of 4th of May, some non-essential shops can reopen.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: As of midnight March 18th 2020, the government of Malta locks down restaurants, bars, gyms, exhibitions, clubs, discotheques, night clubs, open-air markets, indoor swimming pools, massage parlours, gaming premises including controlled gaming premises, bingo halls, casinos, gaming parlours and betting shops. Lottery booths alone will be permitted to reopen from 4th May 2020 with certain restrictions in place.

description:
On 16th March 2020, the government of Malta announces that as of midnight March 18th 2020, it will lock down restaurants, bars, gyms, exhibitions, clubs, discotheques, night clubs, open-air markets, indoor swimming pools, massage parlours, gaming premises including controlled gaming premises, bingo halls, casinos, gaming parlours, lotto booths and betting shops.
 
 UPDATE: The Maltese government has announced that lottery booths alone will be permitted to reopen from 4th May 2020 with certain restrictions in place.

description: From 25th May 2020, fuel stations in Malta will be extending their hours of operation bringing an end to the restrictions in opening hours brought about due to Covid-19. They will now operate from 6 am to 5 pm from Mondays to Fridays and from 6 am to 2 pm on Saturdays. They will also operate by self-service which is available 24 hours a day.

description: On the 10th of March 2020, Malta announces restrictions on mass events. Outdoor events of more than 2000 people are banned. Indoor events limited to 750 people. UPDATE: From August 8th, the number of attendees for an organised public mass event must not exceed one hundred (100)persons inside the venue and three hundred (300) persons outside the venue
date_end_spec: The policy is a one-time measure (e.g. publication of guidelines)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: March 10, 2020: Maltese Prime Minister Robert Abela announced that “St Patrick's day street parties next week [on March 17, 2020] cannot be held”.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description: On 30th of March 2020, Maltese Government announced public gatherings will be limited to 3 people. Police empowered to issue fines of €100 per person in the group. The measure will not apply to bus stops and queues but social distancing rules of a minimum two metres will apply. Family members from the same household will not incur fines if gathering outside in group larger than 3.
date_end_spec: The policy has an unlimited time span (e.g. recommendation to wash one's hands; passing of a legal bill)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: Police,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description:
On 30th of March 2020, Maltese Government announced public gatherings will be limited to 3 people. Police empowered to issue fines of €100 per person in the group. The measure will not apply to bus stops and queues but social distancing rules of a minimum two metres will apply. Family members from the same household will not incur fines if gathering outside in group larger than 3. 

On May 1st Maltese Government announced public gathering restrictions eased to allow groups of 4. Fines of €100 continue. UPDATE: Public gatherings of 4 allowed instead of 3.
date_end_spec: The policy has an unlimited time span (e.g. recommendation to wash one's hands; passing of a legal bill)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
enforcer: Police,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: The Government of Malta announced that from 22nd May 2020, individual non-contact sports such as diving and tennis will be permitted. As for contact sports, outdoors training will be permitted so long as the group is up to a maximum of 6 persons.

description: On the 10th of March 2020, Malta announces restrictions on mass events. Outdoor events of more than 2000 people are banned. Indoor events limited to 750 people. UPDATE: From August 19th, in public spaces groups of more than fifteen (15) persons shall be prohibited. This prohibition shall not apply to groups of persons in public places if the persons live in the same residence

description: From April 1st, any person within Malta who is: (a) inside retail outlets;(b) travelling on public transport;(c) travelling between Malta and Gozo including in the respective Ċirkewwa and Imġarr terminals; (d) within the terminal building of the Malta International Airport; (e) within the terminal building for passengers travelling by catamaran or by cruise-liners; and (f) obtaining a service or visiting indoor public places, shall, at all times, wear a visor or medical or cloth mask.".
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Wearing Masks in all public spaces/everywhere
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
